Section 1:
EXEMPT
FIRST REPRINT S.B. 494
SENATE BILL NO. 494–COMMITTEE ON FINANCE
(ON BEHALF OF THE OFFICE OF FINANCE
IN THE OFFICE OF THE GOVERNOR)
MAY 15, 2025
____________
Referred to Committee on Health and Human Services
SUMMARY—Makes revisions relating to health and human
services. (BDR 18-1116)
FISCAL NOTE: Effect on Local Government: May have Fiscal Impact.
Effect on the State: Executive Budget.
~
EXPLANATION – Matter in bolded italics is new; matter between brackets [omitted material] is material to be omitted.
AN ACT relating to state government; creating the Nevada Health
Authority; creating certain divisions and offices within the
Authority; providing for the appointment of officers and
the employment of staff for the Authority; establishing
requirements governing procurement by the Authority;
creating the Nevada Health Authority Gift Fund;
prescribing the duties of the Authority and its divisions and
officers; transferring to the Authority the responsibility for
operating various programs and administering various
provisions; revising the name of certain agencies; revising
certain terminology; eliminating the Division of Health
Care Financing and Policy of the Department of Health and
Human Services; revising provisions governing the
operation of the Public Employees’ Benefits Program and
Medicaid; requiring certain reporting on the costs of health
insurance for retired state employees; authorizing the
Authority to require the reporting of certain information on
the cost of certain prescription drugs; revising the
membership and duties of the Board of Directors of the
Silver State Health Insurance Exchange; providing for a
study of opportunities for the Board of the Public
Employees’ Benefits Program to directly contract with
certain providers of health care; and providing other
matters properly relating thereto.
-
*SB494_R1*
– 2 –
Legislative Counsel’s Digest:
1 Existing law creates the Department of Health and Human Services, which
2 consists of the Aging and Disability Services Division, the Division of Public and
3 Behavioral Health, the Division of Welfare and Supportive Services, the Division of
4 Child and Family Services and the Division of Health Care Financing and Policy.
5 (NRS 232.300) This bill creates a new department within the Executive Department
6 of the State Government known as the Nevada Health Authority to assume certain
7 responsibilities of the Department of Health and Human Services and other entities
8 related to the management of certain public health insurance plans, the licensing and
9 regulation of certain persons and entities involved in the provision of health care and
10 the regulation of sanitation in food establishments and certain other locations.
11 Section 18 of this bill creates and establishes the purposes of the Authority, and
12 section 32 of this bill changes the name of the Department to the Department of
13 Human Services. Section 18 provides that the Authority consists of: (1) the Medicaid
14 Division; (2) the Health Care Purchasing and Compliance Division; and (3) the
15 Consumer Health Division. Section 19 of this bill requires the Governor to appoint
16 a Director of the Authority who possesses certain qualifications. Sections 20-23 and
17 29 of this bill provide for the appointment of officers and the employment of staff for
18 the Authority, including an administrator of each division of the Authority. Sections
19 24 and 79 of this bill exempt the Authority from provisions of law governing state
20 procurement, with certain exceptions, and section 24 prescribes requirements
21 governing procurement by the Authority. Sections 24 and 61 of this bill provide for
22 the confidentiality of certain information submitted to the Authority during the
23 procurement process. Section 25 of this bill authorizes: (1) the sharing of confidential
24 information within the Authority; and (2) the Authority to share confidential
25 information with certain agencies of local governments in certain circumstances.
26 Sections 26 and 34 of this bill transfer from the Department to the Authority the
27 authority to administer certain programs for persons with developmental disabilities.
28 Section 28 of this bill requires the Director or the Director’s designee to adopt each
29 state plan required by the Federal Government for the administration of any program
30 for which the Authority or a division thereof is responsible. Section 31 of this bill
31 creates the Nevada Health Authority Gift Fund to hold gifts, grants and other property
32 which the Authority is authorized to accept. Sections 113 and 227 of this bill require
33 the deposit of certain money in the Fund. Section 36 of this bill updates the name of
34 the Department of Health and Human Services Gift Fund, which is created by
35 existing law, to conform to the change in the name of the Department. (NRS 232.355)
36 Existing law requires the Office of Science, Innovation and Technology in the
37 Office of the Governor to administer the Graduate Medical Education Grant
38 Program, which is a program to award grants to institutions in this State seeking to
39 create, expand or retain programs for residency training and postdoctoral fellowships
40 for physicians. (NRS 223.631-223.639) Sections 2-8 and 26 of this bill transfer to
41 the Consumer Health Division the responsibility for administering the Program.
42 Existing law requires the Board of the Public Employees’ Benefits Program to
43 establish the Program to provide group life, accident or health insurance, or any
44 combination thereof, to employees of the State Government. (NRS 287.043) Section
45 68 of this bill places the Board within the Authority and makes revisions governing
46 the appointment and membership of the Board. Section 68.5 of this bill: (1) removes
47 the authority of the Governor to designate the Chair of the Board and instead
48 requires the Board to elect a Chair annually; and (2) requires the Governor to
49 designate a Vice Chair of the Board. Section 69 of this bill transfers from the Board
50 to the Director of the Authority the responsibility for appointing the Executive
51 Officer of the Program. Section 65.5 of this bill requires the Board to biennially
52 submit to the Legislature a report concerning the cost for a retired state employee to
53 obtain coverage through the Program under Medicare. Section 70 of this bill requires
54 the Executive Officer to submit to the Authority a report regarding the administration
-
*SB494_R1*
– 3 –
55 and operation of the Program, in addition to certain other entities that currently
56 receive the report. Section 71 of this bill provides that the appointment of officers
57 and unclassified employees to administer the Program is subject to the approval of
58 the Director of the Authority. Sections 72-74 of this bill authorize the Board to utilize
59 certain services of the Authority, including procurement services, or to conduct
60 procurement in accordance with either section 24 or provisions of existing law
61 governing procurement by state agencies. (Chapter 333 of NRS) Section 72
62 additionally requires the Board, within the limits of available resources, to take such
63 measures as are necessary to maximize the benefits available to participants in the
64 Program and the ability of participants to access available benefits.
65 Existing law authorizes the Board of the Program to enter into contracts with
66 physicians, surgeons, hospitals and rehabilitative facilities for medical, surgical and
67 rehabilitative care and the evaluation, treatment and nursing care of members of the
68 Program and covered dependents. (NRS 287.0434) Section 367.7 of this bill requires
69 the Authority and the Board to study and report to the Legislature concerning
70 opportunities to directly contract with such providers.
71 Existing law requires: (1) the Department to administer Medicaid and the
72 Children’s Health Insurance Program; and (2) the Division of Health Care Financing
73 and Policy of the Department to perform certain duties related to the administration
74 of those programs. (Chapter 422 of NRS) Sections 26, 34, 93-96, 113-117, 120.5
75 and 359 of this bill transfer from the Department and the Director of the Department
76 to the Medicaid Division and the Director of the Authority the responsibility for
77 administering Medicaid and the Children’s Health Insurance Program. Sections 32,
78 34 and 35 of this bill abolish the Division of Health Care Financing and Policy, and
79 sections 94 and 359 transfer the authority, duties and responsibilities of that Division
80 to the Medicaid Division. Section 86 of this bill authorizes the Authority to delegate
81 to other governmental entities the responsibility for making determinations of
82 eligibility for Medicaid and the Children’s Health Insurance Program. Section 86.5
83 of this bill prohibits the Authority from requiring a recipient of or applicant for
84 Medicaid to be employed, receive training or volunteer, except when required by the
85 Federal Government. Section 86.5 requires the Director of the Authority to take
86 certain actions to solicit public input and inform the Legislature before implementing
87 such a requirement. Section 87 of this bill creates the Office of the Medicaid
88 Inspector General within the Authority to perform certain duties to ensure the
89 integrity of Medicaid and the Children’s Health Insurance Program and to prevent
90 waste, fraud and abuse in those programs. Sections 66, 88-91 and 371 of this bill
91 transfer or provide to the Authority certain responsibilities related to the
92 administration of those programs. Sections 101-104, 109 and 110 of this bill
93 establish provisions governing the qualifications, supervision and activities of the
94 Administrator of the Medicaid Division, which are similar to the qualifications,
95 supervision and activities of the Administrator of the Division of Health Care
96 Financing and Policy. (NRS 422.2354-422.2364, 422.2372) Sections 105-108, 111
97 and 112 of this bill transfer to the Director certain responsibilities relating to
98 Medicaid and the Children’s Health Insurance Program, including the responsibility
99 for adopting regulations governing those programs. Section 116 requires any
100 contract for the expenditure of federal money under Medicaid to be signed by the
101 Director. Section 118 of this bill requires the Authority to: (1) include on an Internet
102 website maintained by the Authority certain information to allow recipients of
103 Medicaid through managed care to compare available plans; and (2) develop and
104 implement a beneficiary support system for such recipients of Medicaid. Section 371
105 repeals certain fiscal duties previously performed by the Administrator of the
106 Division of Health Care Financing and Policy.
107 Sections 26, 34, 141, 144-146, 194, 217-224, 245-247, 250, 260, 276, 325-327
108 and 360 of this bill transfer from the Division of Public and Behavioral Health to the
109 Health Care Purchasing and Compliance Division and from the Department of Health
-
*SB494_R1*
– 4 –
110 and Human Services to the Nevada Health Authority, as applicable, the
111 responsibilities for credentialing and regulating: (1) programs for the treatment of
112 persons who commit domestic violence; (2) health care facilities and certain entities
113 involved in the provision of personal care services; (3) nontransplant anatomical
114 donation organizations; (4) naprapaths; and (5) medical laboratories and their
115 personnel. Section 143 of this bill authorizes the State Board of Health to establish
116 fees for the credentialing functions and certain other functions of the Health Care
117 Purchasing and Compliance Division. Sections 26, 34 and 162-171 of this bill
118 transfer from the Division of Public and Behavioral Health to the Health Care
119 Purchasing and Compliance Division the responsibility for administering provisions
120 governing health and safety at health care facilities, including the reporting of
121 sentinel events. Section 35 reduces the number of deputy administrators in the
122 Division of Public and Behavioral Health to account for the duties removed from that
123 Division.
124 Sections 26, 34, 141, 144, 145, 147-152, 154-160, 180-187, 197-200, 226-238,
125 240-244 and 359 of this bill transfer from the Department to the Authority the
126 responsibility for administering; (1) the State Program for Oral Health; (2) provisions
127 governing health information technology; (3) the programs to increase public
128 awareness of health care information concerning hospitals and surgical centers for
129 ambulatory patients in this State; (4) provisions governing the reporting of
130 information relating to the cost of certain prescription drugs and certain information
131 concerning pharmacies; (5) the Nevada Health Facilities Assistance Act, which
132 establishes a program to construct new health facilities in this State; and (6) certain
133 requirements to ensure the quality of care offered by hospitals in this State and the
134 financial stability of such hospitals. Section 197 additionally authorizes the
135 Authority to require the reporting of information concerning the cost of certain
136 additional prescription drugs for which reporting is not currently required.
137 Existing law: (1) creates the Patient Protection Commission within the Office of
138 the Director of the Department; and (2) requires the Commission to perform certain
139 duties to improve the quality, accessibility and affordability of health care in this
140 State. (NRS 439.908, 439.918) Sections 26, 34, 172 and 173 of this bill transfer the
141 Commission to the Consumer Health Division. Sections 172 and 173 also transfer
142 from the Governor to the Director of the Authority the responsibility for appointing
143 the members and Executive Director of the Commission. Sections 174 and 175 of
144 this bill require the Commission to make certain recommendations and submit certain
145 reports to the Director of the Authority.
146 Existing law authorizes the Division of Public and Behavioral Health to establish
147 a secure Internet website which makes certain information available for a website
148 client to conduct background investigations of certain persons who are required by
149 law to undergo such an investigation. (NRS 449.942) Sections 175.3 and 175.6 of
150 this bill authorize the Authority to access information on that Internet website without
151 restriction and without becoming a website client.
152 Existing law requires the Department to establish an all-payer claims database of
153 information relating to health insurance claims resulting from medical, dental or
154 pharmacy benefits provided in this State. (NRS 439B.835) Section 29 creates the
155 Office of Data Analytics within the Authority, and sections 26, 34, 202-204 and 359
156 of this bill transfer to the Office the responsibility for operating the all-payer claims
157 database.
158 Existing law: (1) requires the Division of Public and Behavioral Health to enforce
159 provisions governing sanitation and food establishments under certain
160 circumstances; and (2) requires each county where the Division provides such
161 enforcement to pay an assessment to the Division. (NRS 439.4905, chapters 444 and
162 446 of NRS) Sections 26, 34, 206-208 and 210-216 of this bill transfer to the
163 Authority the authority to enforce provisions governing sanitation and food
164 establishments, and sections 30 and 153 of this bill require counties who currently
-
*SB494_R1*
– 5 –
165 pay to the Division an assessment for those functions to instead pay the assessment
166 to the Authority.
167 Existing law requires the State Board of Health to license and regulate music
168 therapists and dietitians. (Chapters 640D and 640E of NRS) Sections 26, 283-297
169 and 300-323 of this bill transfer to the Health Care Purchasing and Compliance
170 Division the responsibilities for issuing and renewing licenses to those professionals
171 and enforcing provisions of law and regulations governing those professionals and
172 leave the authority to adopt regulations governing those professions with the State
173 Board.
174 Existing law creates the Silver State Health Insurance Exchange. (NRS 695I.200)
175 Existing law requires the Exchange to: (1) create and administer a state-based health
176 insurance exchange; (2) facilitate the purchase and sale of qualified health plans; (3)
177 provide for the establishment of a program to help certain small employers in Nevada
178 in facilitating the enrollment of employees in qualified health plans; and (4) perform
179 all other duties required pursuant to the federal Patient Protection and Affordable
180 Care Act, the federal Health Care and Education Reconciliation Act of 2010 and any
181 amendments to or regulations or guidance issued pursuant to those Acts. (Pub. L. No.
182 111-148, Pub. L. No. 111-152; NRS 695I.200, 695I.210) The Exchange is governed
183 by the Board of Directors consisting of five voting members appointed by the
184 Governor, one voting member appointed by the Senate Majority Leader, one voting
185 member appointed by the Speaker of the Assembly and three ex officio, nonvoting
186 members. (NRS 695I.300) Sections 346-348 of this bill place the Exchange under
187 the authority of the Consumer Health Division. Section 348: (1) reduces the number
188 of members of the Board appointed by the Governor from five to two; (2) adds three
189 heads of agencies whose work relates to public health or health insurance as ex
190 officio, voting members of the Board; and (3) reduces the nonvoting membership of
191 the Board. Sections 349 and 350 of this bill make revisions governing the terms of
192 the members and officers of the Board. Section 352 of this bill transfers from the
193 Board to the Director of the Authority or his or her designee the responsibility for
194 appointing the Executive Director of the Exchange. Sections 351 and 352 of this bill
195 transfer certain duties relating to auditing and reports from the Board to the Executive
196 Director. Sections 353 and 354 of this bill transfer certain other duties related to the
197 Exchange to Authority and its Director.
198 Existing law requires the Director of the Department, in consultation with the
199 Commissioner of Insurance and the Executive Director of the Exchange, to design,
200 establish and operate a health benefit plan known as the Public Option. (NRS
201 695K.200) Section 355 of this bill transfers the responsibility for designing,
202 establishing and operating the Public Option to the Director of the Authority.
203 Section 27 of this bill requires the Director and the Authority to: (1) take certain
204 actions to facilitate determinations of eligibility for and the selection of plans under
205 Medicaid and certain other public health insurance programs under the jurisdiction
206 of the Authority; and (2) assess and recommend improvements to the Public
207 Employees’ Benefits Program. Sections 9-13, 38-60, 62, 77, 78, 80, 81, 83, 96-98,
208 100, 121, 123, 125, 128-139, 142, 161, 178, 179, 188, 189, 195, 196, 205, 209, 248,
209 249, 251-275, 277-280, 324, 328-336, 338-341 and 356-358 of this bill make various
210 conforming changes to reflect the authority transferred by the provisions of this bill.
211 Sections 32, 34, 38, 46, 99, 122, 127, 239, 287, 307 and 326 of this bill change the
212 name of the Division of Welfare and Supportive Services of the Department to the
213 Division of Social Services of the Department. Sections 33, 37, 82, 119, 120, 123,
214 124, 126-128 and 368 of this bill revise the terminology to refer to certain programs
215 operated by that Division from “welfare” to “public assistance.” Section 132 revises
216 the term “transitional assistance” to “child care assistance” to describe certain
217 assistance provided pursuant to federal Temporary Assistance for Needy Families
218 program. Sections 1, 16, 17, 64, 65, 85, 140, 176, 191, 192, 225, 240, 281, 298, 343
219 and 344 of this bill define certain terms, and sections 15, 67, 75, 76, 92, 177, 193,
-
*SB494_R1*
– 6 –
220 201, 282, 299, 337 and 345 of this bill make conforming changes to indicate the
221 applicability of those definitions. Section 371 eliminates certain definitions that are
222 no longer necessary. Sections 58.5 and 120.5 of this bill authorize the Board of State
223 Prison Commissioners to obtain prescription drugs for the treatment of offenders
224 through collaborative purchasing conducted by the Authority for Medicaid and
225 certain public and nonprofit health plans.
226 Section 361 of this bill transfers to the Authority the duty to carry out any
227 requirements of a bill that is enacted by the Legislature during this session and
228 approved by the Governor to: (1) require the Department of Health and Human
229 Services to operate a program to award money to support projects to address
230 shortages of providers of health care in this State; or (2) impose certain requirements
231 on Medicaid or the Children’s Health Insurance Program.

SENATE AND ASSEMBLY, DO ENACT AS FOLLOWS:

2 thereto a new section to read as follows:

37 Sec. 3. NRS 223.630 is hereby amended to read as follows:
38 223.630 1. The Account for the Office of Science, Innovation
39 and Technology is hereby created in the State General Fund. The
40 Account must be administered by the Director of the Office of
41 Science, Innovation and Technology.
42 2. Except as otherwise provided in NRS [223.631 and] 223.660,
43 any money accepted pursuant to NRS 223.620 must be deposited in
44 the Account.
-
*SB494_R1*
– 8 –
1 3. The interest and income earned on the money in the Account,
2 after deducting any applicable charges, must be credited to the
3 Account.
4 4. The money in the Account must only be used to carry out the
5 duties of the Director.
6 5. Claims against the Account must be paid as other claims
7 against the State are paid.
8 Sec. 4. NRS 223.631 is hereby amended to read as follows:
9 223.631 1. The Account for the Graduate Medical Education
10 Grant Program is hereby created in the State General Fund. The
11 Director of the [Office of Science, Innovation and Technology]
12 Nevada Health Authority, or his or her designee, shall administer
13 the Account.
14 2. The Director of the [Office of Science, Innovation and
15 Technology] Nevada Health Authority, or his or her designee, may:
16 (a) Accept any gift, donation, bequest or devise; and
17 (b) Apply for and accept any grant, loan or other source of money,
18  for deposit in the Account to assist the Director in carrying out the
19 Graduate Medical Education Grant Program established pursuant to
20 NRS 223.637.
21 3. The interest and income earned on the money in the Account,
22 after deducting any applicable charges, must be credited to the
23 Account.
24 4. The money in the Account must only be used to:
25 (a) Award competitive grants to institutions in this State seeking
26 to create, expand or retain programs for residency training and
27 postdoctoral fellowships that are approved by the Accreditation
28 Council for Graduate Medical Education or its successor
29 organization; and
30 (b) Defray the costs of establishing and administering the
31 Graduate Medical Education Grant Program established pursuant to
32 NRS 223.637.
33 5. Any money remaining in the Account at the end of the fiscal
34 year does not revert to the State General Fund, and the balance in the
35 Account must be carried forward to the next fiscal year.
36 6. Claims against the Account must be paid as other claims
37 against the State are paid.

39 223.633 1. The Advisory Council on Graduate Medical
40 Education is hereby created within the [Office of Science, Innovation
41 and Technology.] Division. The Council consists of:
42 (a) The dean of each medical school in this State that is accredited
43 by the Liaison Committee on Medical Education of the American
44 Medical Association and the Association of American Medical
45 Colleges or their successor organizations, or his or her designee;
-
*SB494_R1*
– 9 –
1 (b) The dean of each school of osteopathic medicine in this State
2 that is accredited by the Commission on Osteopathic College
3 Accreditation of the American Osteopathic Association or its
4 successor organization, or his or her designee;
5 (c) Two members appointed by the Governor who are physicians
6 licensed pursuant to chapter 630 or 633 of NRS;
7 (d) One member appointed by the Governor who represents
8 hospitals located in counties whose population is less than 100,000;
9 (e) One member appointed by the Governor who represents
10 hospitals located in counties whose population is 100,000 or more but
11 less than 700,000;
12 (f) One member appointed by the Governor who represents
13 hospitals located in a county whose population is 700,000 or more;
14 (g) One member appointed by the Governor who represents the
15 medical corps of any of the Armed Forces of the United States;
16 (h) One member appointed by the Governor who represents the
17 Department of [Health and] Human Services; and
18 (i) One member appointed by the Governor who represents the
19 Office of Economic Development in the Office of the Governor.
20 2. In addition to the members appointed by the Governor
21 pursuant to subsection 1, the Governor may appoint two members as
22 the Governor determines necessary to carry out the provisions of NRS
23 223.631 to 223.639, inclusive.
24 3. After the initial terms, the term of each member of the Council
25 is 3 years, and members shall serve at the pleasure of the Governor.
26 4. Any vacancy occurring in the membership of the Council
27 must be filled in the same manner as the original appointment not
28 later than 30 days after the vacancy occurs.
29 5. The Council shall select from its members a Chair and a Vice
30 Chair who shall hold office for 1 year and who may be reselected.
31 6. The Council shall meet at the call of the Chair as often as
32 necessary to evaluate applications for competitive grants for the
33 Graduate Medical Education Grant Program established pursuant to
34 NRS 223.637 and make recommendations to the [Office of Science,
35 Innovation and Technology] Division concerning the approval of
36 applications for such grants.
37 7. A majority of the members of the Council constitutes a
38 quorum for the transaction of business, and a majority of those
39 members present at any meeting is sufficient for any official action
40 taken by the Council.
41 8. The members of the Council serve without compensation,
42 except that each member is entitled to receive the per diem allowance
43 and travel expenses provided for state officers and employees
44 generally while engaged in the official business of the Council.

1 9. A member of the Council who is an officer or employee of
2 this State or a political subdivision of this State must be relieved from
3 his or her duties without loss of regular compensation to prepare for

31 (b) The recruitment and retention of physicians necessary to meet
32 the health care needs of the residents of this State, with the emphasis
33 on those health care needs.

18 Sec. 8. NRS 223.639 is hereby amended to read as follows:
19 223.639 1. On or before October 1 of each year, the [Office of
20 Science, Innovation and Technology] Division shall submit a written
21 report to:
22 (a) The Governor; and
23 (b) The Director of the Legislative Counsel Bureau for transmittal
24 to:

1 Sec. 14. Chapter 232 of NRS is hereby amended by adding
2 thereto the provisions set forth as sections 15 to 31, inclusive, of this
3 act.
4 Sec. 15. As used in sections 15 to 31, inclusive, of this act,

8 Sec. 16. “Authority” means the Nevada Health Authority.
9 Sec. 17. “Director” means the Director of the Authority.
10 Sec. 18. 1. The Nevada Health Authority is hereby created
11 as a department within the Executive Department of the State
12 Government.
13 2. The purposes of the Authority are to:
14 (a) Improve access to health care that is safe, of high quality
15 and affordable;
16 (b) Promote the development of a workforce of providers of
17 health care that is sufficient to meet the demand for health care in
18 this State;
19 (c) Ensure the availability of affordable health coverage for
20 residents of this State, including, without limitation, current and
21 retired employees of the State Government;
22 (d) Develop effective and efficient systems for delivering health
23 care and value-based strategies for procuring health insurance
24 coverage in the most sustainable and responsive manner possible;
25 and
26 (e) Ensure the long-term stability of Medicaid, the Children’s
27 Health Insurance Program, the Public Employees’ Benefits
28 Program, the Silver State Health Insurance Exchange and the
29 Public Option by minimizing the financial burden of health care on
30 persons who receive health coverage through those programs, the
31 state budget and other residents of this State through the use of
32 measures to contain costs, maximizing the impact of state and
33 federal money and the application of innovative purchasing and
34 contracting strategies.
35 3. The Authority consists of a Director and:
36 (a) The Medicaid Division;
37 (b) The Health Care Purchasing and Compliance Division; and
38 (c) The Consumer Health Division.
39 4. The Authority is the sole agency responsible for
40 administering the provisions of law relating to its respective
41 divisions.
42 Sec. 19. The Director:
43 1. Is appointed by, is responsible to, and serves at the pleasure
44 of the Governor.
45 2. Is in the unclassified service of the State.
-
*SB494_R1*
– 18 –
1 3. Except as otherwise provided in NRS 284.143, shall not
2 engage in any other gainful employment or occupation.
3 4. Must have:
4 (a) A graduate degree from an accredited college or university
5 in public health, public administration, law or a related field; and
6 (b) Broad, responsible experience in the field of administration
7 or possess broad management skills or working knowledge of the
8 field of health care or public health administration.
9 5. Must be selected with special reference to his or her
10 training, experience and aptitude for coordinating related functions
11 of public health agencies and public health insurance programs.
12 The Director’s knowledge and abilities should include the
13 following:
14 (a) A comprehensive knowledge of administrative principles,
15 and a working knowledge of principles of public finance and the
16 laws, rules and regulations pertaining to public agencies.
17 (b) Administrative ability to assess the operating efficiency of
18 component agencies and to delegate authority and duties to
19 responsible deputy directors or other personnel of the Authority.
20 (c) The ability to organize and clearly present oral and written
21 findings and recommendations to the Governor, the Legislature
22 and other officials and agencies.
23 Sec. 20. 1. The Director may employ, within the limits of
24 legislative appropriations, such staff as is necessary to the

36 the matter in the capacity of his or her employment with the
37 Authority.

-
*SB494_R1*
– 27 –
1 the Authority pursuant to chapters 444 and 446 of NRS and the
2 regulations adopted pursuant to those chapters. If the Governor
3 approves the proposal, the Governor shall submit a
4 recommendation to the Interim Finance Committee to exempt the
5 county from the assessment required pursuant to subsection 1. The
6 Interim Finance Committee, upon receiving the recommendation
7 from the Governor, shall consider the proposal and determine
8 whether to approve the exemption. In considering whether to
9 approve the exemption, the Interim Finance Committee shall
10 consider, among other things, the best interests of the State, the
11 effect of the exemption and the intent of the Legislature in requiring
12 the assessment to be paid by each county.

23 Sec. 31. 1. Except for gifts or grants specifically accounted
24 for in another fund, all gifts or grants of money or other property
25 which the divisions of the Authority are authorized to accept must

28 continuing fund without reversion. The Authority may establish
29 such accounts in the Fund as are necessary to account properly for
30 gifts received. All such money received by the divisions of the
31 Authority must be deposited in the State Treasury for credit to the
32 Fund. The money in the Fund must be paid out on claims as other
33 claims against the State are paid. Unless otherwise specifically
34 provided by statute, claims against the Fund must be approved by
35 the Director or the Director’s delegate.
36 2. Gifts of property other than money may be sold or
37 exchanged when this is deemed by the head of the agency
38 responsible for the gift to be in the best interest of the agency. The
39 sale price must not be less than 90 percent of the value determined
40 by a qualified appraiser appointed by the head of the agency. All
41 money received from the sale must be deposited in the State
42 Treasury to the credit of the appropriate gift account in the Nevada
43 Health Authority Gift Fund. The money may be spent only for the
44 purposes of the agency named in the title of the account. The
-

37 38 and 41 of chapter 478, Statutes of Nevada 2011 and section 2 of
38 chapter 391, Statutes of Nevada 2013 and unless otherwise declared
39 by law to be confidential, all public books and public records of a
40 governmental entity must be open at all times during office hours to
41 inspection by any person, and may be fully copied or an abstract or
42 memorandum may be prepared from those public books and public
43 records. Any such copies, abstracts or memoranda may be used to
44 supply the general public with copies, abstracts or memoranda of the
45 records or may be used in any other way to the advantage of the
-
*SB494_R1*
– 72 –
1 governmental entity or of the general public. This section does not
2 supersede or in any manner affect the federal laws governing
3 copyrights or enlarge, diminish or affect in any other manner the
4 rights of a person in any written book or record which is copyrighted
5 pursuant to federal law.
6 2. A governmental entity may not reject a book or record which
7 is copyrighted solely because it is copyrighted.
8 3. A governmental entity that has legal custody or control of a
9 public book or record shall not deny a request made pursuant to
10 subsection 1 to inspect or copy or receive a copy of a public book or
11 record on the basis that the requested public book or record contains
12 information that is confidential if the governmental entity can redact,
13 delete, conceal or separate, including, without limitation,
14 electronically, the confidential information from the information
15 included in the public book or record that is not otherwise
16 confidential.
17 4. If requested, a governmental entity shall provide a copy of a
18 public record in an electronic format by means of an electronic
19 medium. Nothing in this subsection requires a governmental entity to
20 provide a copy of a public record in an electronic format or by means
21 of an electronic medium if:
22 (a) The public record:
23 (1) Was not created or prepared in an electronic format; and
24 (2) Is not available in an electronic format; or
25 (b) Providing the public record in an electronic format or by
26 means of an electronic medium would:
27 (1) Give access to proprietary software; or
28 (2) Require the production of information that is confidential
29 and that cannot be redacted, deleted, concealed or separated from
30 information that is not otherwise confidential.
31 5. An officer, employee or agent of a governmental entity who
32 has legal custody or control of a public record:
33 (a) Shall not refuse to provide a copy of that public record in the
34 medium that is requested because the officer, employee or agent has
35 already prepared or would prefer to provide the copy in a different
36 medium.
37 (b) Except as otherwise provided in NRS 239.030, shall, upon
38 request, prepare the copy of the public record and shall not require
39 the person who has requested the copy to prepare the copy himself or
40 herself.

5 Sec. 86. 1. The Authority may delegate to another state,
6 local or tribal governmental agency the responsibility for making
7 determinations concerning eligibility for Medicaid or the

9 under this chapter. If the Authority makes such a delegation, the

12 431.10; and

24 local or tribal governmental agency to which the Authority has
25 delegated a function.

3 upon receiving the recommendation from the Governor, shall
4 consider the proposal and determine whether to approve the
5 exemption. In considering whether to approve the exemption,
6 the Interim Finance Committee shall consider, among other things,
7 the best interests of the State, the effect of the exemption and the
8 intent of the Legislature in requiring the assessment to be paid by each
9 county.
10 4. An exemption that is approved by the Interim Finance
11 Committee pursuant to subsection 3 must not become effective until
12 at least 6 months after that approval.
13 5. A county that receives approval pursuant to subsection 3 to
14 carry out the services that would otherwise be provided by the
15 Division or the Chief Medical Officer pursuant to this chapter and
16 chapters 441A [, 444, 446] and 583 of NRS and the regulations
17 adopted pursuant to those chapters shall carry out those services in
18 the manner set forth in those chapters and regulations.

*SB494_R1*

9 (4) The extent to which the project is consistent with the

16 repetitive testing;
17 (III) The impact of the project on disparate health
18 outcomes for different populations in the area that will be served by
19 the project;
20 (IV) The manner in which the project will expand, promote
21 or enhance the capacity to provide primary health care in the area that
22 will be served by the project;

24 concerning the effect of the project on health care quality and patient
25 outcomes in the area served by the project;

18 (a) Refuse to accept or treat a patient in need of emergency

20 (b) Except when medically necessary in the judgment of the
21 attending physician:
22 (1) Transfer a patient to another hospital or health facility
23 unless, as documented in the patient’s records:
24 (I) A determination has been made that the patient is
25 medically fit for transfer;
26 (II) Consent to the transfer has been given by the receiving
27 physician, hospital or health facility;
28 (III) The patient has been provided with an explanation of
29 the need for the transfer; and
30 (IV) Consent to the transfer has been given by the patient
31 or the patient’s legal representative; or
32 (2) Provide a patient with orders for testing at another hospital
33 or health facility when the hospital from which the orders are issued
34 is capable of providing that testing.
35 3. A physician, hospital or other health facility which treats a

37 physician working in the hospital is entitled to recover from that
38 hospital an amount equal to three times the charges for the treatment
39 provided that was billed by the physician, hospital or other health

41 and costs.

-
*SB494_R1*
– 166 –
1 (a) When the patient is covered by an insurance policy or other

5 indigent patient has exhausted the money which may be appropriated
6 for that purpose pursuant to NRS 428.050, 428.285 and 450.425; or
7 (c) When the hospital cannot provide the services needed by the
8 patient.
9  No transfer may be made pursuant to this subsection until the
10 patient’s condition has been stabilized to a degree that allows the
11 transfer without an additional risk to the patient.
12 5. As used in this section:
13 (a) “Emergency services and care” means medical screening,
14 examination and evaluation by a physician or, to the extent permitted
15 by a specific statute, by a person under the supervision of a physician,
16 to determine if an emergency medical condition or active labor exists
17 and, if it does, the care, treatment and surgery by a physician
18 necessary to relieve or eliminate the emergency medical condition or
19 active labor, within the capability of the hospital. As used in this
20 paragraph:
21 (1) “Active labor” means, in relation to childbirth, labor that
22 occurs when:
23 (I) There is inadequate time before delivery to transfer the
24 patient safely to another hospital; or
25 (II) A transfer may pose a threat to the health and safety of
26 the patient or the unborn child.
27 (2) “Emergency medical condition” means the presence of
28 acute symptoms of sufficient severity, including severe pain, such
29 that the absence of immediate medical attention could reasonably be
30 expected to result in:
31 (I) Placing the health of the patient in serious jeopardy;
32 (II) Serious impairment of bodily functions; or
33 (III) Serious dysfunction of any bodily organ or part.
34 (b) “Medically fit” means that the condition of the patient has
35 been sufficiently stabilized so that the patient may be safely
36 transported to another hospital, or is such that, in the determination
37 of the attending physician, the transfer of the patient constitutes an
38 acceptable risk. Such a determination must be based upon the
39 condition of the patient, the expected benefits, if any, to the patient
40 resulting from the transfer and whether the risks to the patient’s health
41 are outweighed by the expected benefits, and must be documented in
42 the patient’s records before the transfer.

28 (a) The date and time the sealed container is opened;
29 (b) The name of the patient for whom the drugs are to be used;
30 (c) The name of the patient’s physician or the physician who
31 directs the administration of the drugs, if different;
32 (d) An itemization of the drugs removed; and
33 (e) The signature of the person who opened the sealed container.
34 4. When the drugs have been removed and the information
35 required by subsection 3 has been entered on the inventory, the
36 physician or registered nurse shall immediately replace the container
37 in a locked compartment and shall notify the pharmaceutical
38 consultant, as soon as it is practical to do so, that the container has
39 been opened.
40 5. The sealed container and its contents at all times remain the
41 responsibility of the pharmaceutical consultant. Upon being notified
42 that the sealed container has been opened, or on the next business day
43 if notification is not received during business hours, but in no event
44 more than 48 hours following receipt of the notification, the
45 pharmaceutical consultant shall:
-
*SB494_R1*
– 219 –
1 (a) Examine the inventory sheet;
2 (b) Replace the drugs removed;
3 (c) Secure a written prescription for the drugs replaced, if one is
4 required by law;
5 (d) Enter the name and quantity of the drugs so replaced on the
6 inventory sheet, together with the date and time of replacement;
7 (e) Reseal the container; and
8 (f) Sign the inventory sheet.
9 6. No person other than a licensed physician or registered nurse
10 may open the container or remove any drugs from the container.
11 7. The Board, its agents and inspectors may at all times have
12 access to the premises of the facility to determine compliance with
13 this section.

16 639.23275 1. Except as otherwise provided in NRS 453.256,
17 no pharmacy may deliver a controlled substance or dangerous drug

19 intermediate care or facility for skilled nursing which is licensed as
20 such by the Health Care Purchasing and Compliance Division of
21 [Public and Behavioral Health of the Department of Health and
22 Human Services] the Nevada Health Authority which does not have
23 a pharmacy on the premises except pursuant to a prescription given:
24 (a) Directly from the prescribing practitioner to a pharmacist;
25 (b) Indirectly by means of an order signed by the prescribing
26 practitioner; or
27 (c) By an oral order transmitted by an agent of the prescribing
28 practitioner.
29 2. If an order for entry on a chart is given by a prescribing
30 practitioner, the chart order must be signed by the practitioner who

24 covered entity or contract pharmacy on the basis that the covered
25 entity or contract pharmacy dispenses a 340B drug or otherwise limit
26 the ability of a covered entity or contract pharmacy to receive the full
27 benefit of purchasing the 340B drug at or below the ceiling price, as
28 calculated pursuant to 42 U.S.C. § 256b(a)(1);
29 (c) Exclude a covered entity or contract pharmacy from any
30 network because the covered entity or contract pharmacy dispenses a
31 340B drug;
32 (d) Restrict the ability of a person to receive a 340B drug,
33 including, without limitation, by imposing a copayment, coinsurance,
34 deductible or other cost-sharing obligation on the drug that is
35 different from a similar drug on the basis that the drug is a 340B drug;
36 (e) Restrict the methods by which a covered entity or contract
37 pharmacy may dispense or deliver a 340B drug or the entity through
38 which a covered entity may dispense or deliver such a drug in a
39 manner that does not apply to drugs that are not 340B drugs; or
40 (f) Prohibit a covered entity or contract pharmacy from
41 purchasing a 340B drug or interfere with the ability of a covered
42 entity or contract pharmacy to purchase a 340B drug.
43 2. This section does not prohibit the [Department of Health and
44 Human Services,] Nevada Health Authority, the Medicaid Division
45 of [Health Care Financing and Policy of the Department of Health
-
*SB494_R1*
– 243 –
1 and Human Services] the Nevada Health Authority or a Medicaid
2 managed care organization from taking such actions as are necessary
3 to:
4 (a) Prevent duplicate discounts or rebates where prohibited by 42
5 U.S.C. § 256b(a)(5)(A); or
6 (b) Ensure the financial stability of the Medicaid program,
7 including, without limitation, by including or enforcing provisions in
8 any relevant contract.
9 3. As used in this section:
10 (a) “340B drug” means a prescription drug that is purchased by a
11 covered entity under the 340B Program.
12 (b) “340B Program” means the drug pricing program established
13 by the United States Secretary of Health and Human Services
14 pursuant to section 340B of the Public Health Service Act, 42 U.S.C.
15 § 256b, as amended.
16 (c) “Contract pharmacy” means a pharmacy that enters into a
17 contract with a covered entity to dispense 340B drugs and provide
18 related pharmacy services to the patients of the covered entity.
19 (d) “Covered entity” has the meaning ascribed to it in 42 U.S.C.
20 § 256b(a)(4).
21 (e) “Medicaid managed care organization” has the meaning
22 ascribed to it in 42 U.S.C. § 1396b(m).

8 Sec. 369. 1. Any administrative regulations adopted by an
9 officer or an agency whose name has been changed or whose
10 responsibilities have been transferred pursuant to the provisions of
11 this act to another officer or agency remain in force until amended by
12 the officer or agency to which the responsibility for the adoption of
13 the regulations has been transferred.
14 2. Any contracts or other agreements entered into by an officer
15 or agency whose name has been changed or whose responsibilities
16 have been transferred pursuant to the provisions of this act to another
17 officer or agency are binding upon the officer or agency to which the
18 responsibility for the administration of the provisions of the contract
19 or other agreement has been transferred. Such contracts and other
20 agreements may be enforced by the officer or agency to which the
21 responsibility for the enforcement of the provisions of the contract or
22 other agreement has been transferred.
23 3. Any action taken by an officer or agency whose name has
24 been changed or whose responsibilities have been transferred
25 pursuant to the provisions of this act to another officer or agency
26 remains in effect as if taken by the officer or agency to which the
27 responsibility for the enforcement of such actions has been
28 transferred.

Raw Text:
EXEMPT
(Reprinted with amendments adopted on May 30, 2025)
FIRST REPRINT S.B. 494
SENATE BILL NO. 494–COMMITTEE ON FINANCE
(ON BEHALF OF THE OFFICE OF FINANCE
IN THE OFFICE OF THE GOVERNOR)
MAY 15, 2025
____________
Referred to Committee on Health and Human Services
SUMMARY—Makes revisions relating to health and human
services. (BDR 18-1116)
FISCAL NOTE: Effect on Local Government: May have Fiscal Impact.
Effect on the State: Executive Budget.
~
EXPLANATION – Matter in bolded italics is new; matter between brackets [omitted material] is material to be omitted.
AN ACT relating to state government; creating the Nevada Health
Authority; creating certain divisions and offices within the
Authority; providing for the appointment of officers and
the employment of staff for the Authority; establishing
requirements governing procurement by the Authority;
creating the Nevada Health Authority Gift Fund;
prescribing the duties of the Authority and its divisions and
officers; transferring to the Authority the responsibility for
operating various programs and administering various
provisions; revising the name of certain agencies; revising
certain terminology; eliminating the Division of Health
Care Financing and Policy of the Department of Health and
Human Services; revising provisions governing the
operation of the Public Employees’ Benefits Program and
Medicaid; requiring certain reporting on the costs of health
insurance for retired state employees; authorizing the
Authority to require the reporting of certain information on
the cost of certain prescription drugs; revising the
membership and duties of the Board of Directors of the
Silver State Health Insurance Exchange; providing for a
study of opportunities for the Board of the Public
Employees’ Benefits Program to directly contract with
certain providers of health care; and providing other
matters properly relating thereto.
-
*SB494_R1*

– 2 –
Legislative Counsel’s Digest:
1 Existing law creates the Department of Health and Human Services, which
2 consists of the Aging and Disability Services Division, the Division of Public and
3 Behavioral Health, the Division of Welfare and Supportive Services, the Division of
4 Child and Family Services and the Division of Health Care Financing and Policy.
5 (NRS 232.300) This bill creates a new department within the Executive Department
6 of the State Government known as the Nevada Health Authority to assume certain
7 responsibilities of the Department of Health and Human Services and other entities
8 related to the management of certain public health insurance plans, the licensing and
9 regulation of certain persons and entities involved in the provision of health care and
10 the regulation of sanitation in food establishments and certain other locations.
11 Section 18 of this bill creates and establishes the purposes of the Authority, and
12 section 32 of this bill changes the name of the Department to the Department of
13 Human Services. Section 18 provides that the Authority consists of: (1) the Medicaid
14 Division; (2) the Health Care Purchasing and Compliance Division; and (3) the
15 Consumer Health Division. Section 19 of this bill requires the Governor to appoint
16 a Director of the Authority who possesses certain qualifications. Sections 20-23 and
17 29 of this bill provide for the appointment of officers and the employment of staff for
18 the Authority, including an administrator of each division of the Authority. Sections
19 24 and 79 of this bill exempt the Authority from provisions of law governing state
20 procurement, with certain exceptions, and section 24 prescribes requirements
21 governing procurement by the Authority. Sections 24 and 61 of this bill provide for
22 the confidentiality of certain information submitted to the Authority during the
23 procurement process. Section 25 of this bill authorizes: (1) the sharing of confidential
24 information within the Authority; and (2) the Authority to share confidential
25 information with certain agencies of local governments in certain circumstances.
26 Sections 26 and 34 of this bill transfer from the Department to the Authority the
27 authority to administer certain programs for persons with developmental disabilities.
28 Section 28 of this bill requires the Director or the Director’s designee to adopt each
29 state plan required by the Federal Government for the administration of any program
30 for which the Authority or a division thereof is responsible. Section 31 of this bill
31 creates the Nevada Health Authority Gift Fund to hold gifts, grants and other property
32 which the Authority is authorized to accept. Sections 113 and 227 of this bill require
33 the deposit of certain money in the Fund. Section 36 of this bill updates the name of
34 the Department of Health and Human Services Gift Fund, which is created by
35 existing law, to conform to the change in the name of the Department. (NRS 232.355)
36 Existing law requires the Office of Science, Innovation and Technology in the
37 Office of the Governor to administer the Graduate Medical Education Grant
38 Program, which is a program to award grants to institutions in this State seeking to
39 create, expand or retain programs for residency training and postdoctoral fellowships
40 for physicians. (NRS 223.631-223.639) Sections 2-8 and 26 of this bill transfer to
41 the Consumer Health Division the responsibility for administering the Program.
42 Existing law requires the Board of the Public Employees’ Benefits Program to
43 establish the Program to provide group life, accident or health insurance, or any
44 combination thereof, to employees of the State Government. (NRS 287.043) Section
45 68 of this bill places the Board within the Authority and makes revisions governing
46 the appointment and membership of the Board. Section 68.5 of this bill: (1) removes
47 the authority of the Governor to designate the Chair of the Board and instead
48 requires the Board to elect a Chair annually; and (2) requires the Governor to
49 designate a Vice Chair of the Board. Section 69 of this bill transfers from the Board
50 to the Director of the Authority the responsibility for appointing the Executive
51 Officer of the Program. Section 65.5 of this bill requires the Board to biennially
52 submit to the Legislature a report concerning the cost for a retired state employee to
53 obtain coverage through the Program under Medicare. Section 70 of this bill requires
54 the Executive Officer to submit to the Authority a report regarding the administration
-
*SB494_R1*

– 3 –
55 and operation of the Program, in addition to certain other entities that currently
56 receive the report. Section 71 of this bill provides that the appointment of officers
57 and unclassified employees to administer the Program is subject to the approval of
58 the Director of the Authority. Sections 72-74 of this bill authorize the Board to utilize
59 certain services of the Authority, including procurement services, or to conduct
60 procurement in accordance with either section 24 or provisions of existing law
61 governing procurement by state agencies. (Chapter 333 of NRS) Section 72
62 additionally requires the Board, within the limits of available resources, to take such
63 measures as are necessary to maximize the benefits available to participants in the
64 Program and the ability of participants to access available benefits.
65 Existing law authorizes the Board of the Program to enter into contracts with
66 physicians, surgeons, hospitals and rehabilitative facilities for medical, surgical and
67 rehabilitative care and the evaluation, treatment and nursing care of members of the
68 Program and covered dependents. (NRS 287.0434) Section 367.7 of this bill requires
69 the Authority and the Board to study and report to the Legislature concerning
70 opportunities to directly contract with such providers.
71 Existing law requires: (1) the Department to administer Medicaid and the
72 Children’s Health Insurance Program; and (2) the Division of Health Care Financing
73 and Policy of the Department to perform certain duties related to the administration
74 of those programs. (Chapter 422 of NRS) Sections 26, 34, 93-96, 113-117, 120.5
75 and 359 of this bill transfer from the Department and the Director of the Department
76 to the Medicaid Division and the Director of the Authority the responsibility for
77 administering Medicaid and the Children’s Health Insurance Program. Sections 32,
78 34 and 35 of this bill abolish the Division of Health Care Financing and Policy, and
79 sections 94 and 359 transfer the authority, duties and responsibilities of that Division
80 to the Medicaid Division. Section 86 of this bill authorizes the Authority to delegate
81 to other governmental entities the responsibility for making determinations of
82 eligibility for Medicaid and the Children’s Health Insurance Program. Section 86.5
83 of this bill prohibits the Authority from requiring a recipient of or applicant for
84 Medicaid to be employed, receive training or volunteer, except when required by the
85 Federal Government. Section 86.5 requires the Director of the Authority to take
86 certain actions to solicit public input and inform the Legislature before implementing
87 such a requirement. Section 87 of this bill creates the Office of the Medicaid
88 Inspector General within the Authority to perform certain duties to ensure the
89 integrity of Medicaid and the Children’s Health Insurance Program and to prevent
90 waste, fraud and abuse in those programs. Sections 66, 88-91 and 371 of this bill
91 transfer or provide to the Authority certain responsibilities related to the
92 administration of those programs. Sections 101-104, 109 and 110 of this bill
93 establish provisions governing the qualifications, supervision and activities of the
94 Administrator of the Medicaid Division, which are similar to the qualifications,
95 supervision and activities of the Administrator of the Division of Health Care
96 Financing and Policy. (NRS 422.2354-422.2364, 422.2372) Sections 105-108, 111
97 and 112 of this bill transfer to the Director certain responsibilities relating to
98 Medicaid and the Children’s Health Insurance Program, including the responsibility
99 for adopting regulations governing those programs. Section 116 requires any
100 contract for the expenditure of federal money under Medicaid to be signed by the
101 Director. Section 118 of this bill requires the Authority to: (1) include on an Internet
102 website maintained by the Authority certain information to allow recipients of
103 Medicaid through managed care to compare available plans; and (2) develop and
104 implement a beneficiary support system for such recipients of Medicaid. Section 371
105 repeals certain fiscal duties previously performed by the Administrator of the
106 Division of Health Care Financing and Policy.
107 Sections 26, 34, 141, 144-146, 194, 217-224, 245-247, 250, 260, 276, 325-327
108 and 360 of this bill transfer from the Division of Public and Behavioral Health to the
109 Health Care Purchasing and Compliance Division and from the Department of Health

110 and Human Services to the Nevada Health Authority, as applicable, the
111 responsibilities for credentialing and regulating: (1) programs for the treatment of
112 persons who commit domestic violence; (2) health care facilities and certain entities
113 involved in the provision of personal care services; (3) nontransplant anatomical
114 donation organizations; (4) naprapaths; and (5) medical laboratories and their
115 personnel. Section 143 of this bill authorizes the State Board of Health to establish
116 fees for the credentialing functions and certain other functions of the Health Care
117 Purchasing and Compliance Division. Sections 26, 34 and 162-171 of this bill
118 transfer from the Division of Public and Behavioral Health to the Health Care
119 Purchasing and Compliance Division the responsibility for administering provisions
120 governing health and safety at health care facilities, including the reporting of
121 sentinel events. Section 35 reduces the number of deputy administrators in the
122 Division of Public and Behavioral Health to account for the duties removed from that
123 Division.
124 Sections 26, 34, 141, 144, 145, 147-152, 154-160, 180-187, 197-200, 226-238,
125 240-244 and 359 of this bill transfer from the Department to the Authority the
126 responsibility for administering; (1) the State Program for Oral Health; (2) provisions
127 governing health information technology; (3) the programs to increase public
128 awareness of health care information concerning hospitals and surgical centers for
129 ambulatory patients in this State; (4) provisions governing the reporting of
130 information relating to the cost of certain prescription drugs and certain information
131 concerning pharmacies; (5) the Nevada Health Facilities Assistance Act, which
132 establishes a program to construct new health facilities in this State; and (6) certain
133 requirements to ensure the quality of care offered by hospitals in this State and the
134 financial stability of such hospitals. Section 197 additionally authorizes the
135 Authority to require the reporting of information concerning the cost of certain
136 additional prescription drugs for which reporting is not currently required.
137 Existing law: (1) creates the Patient Protection Commission within the Office of
138 the Director of the Department; and (2) requires the Commission to perform certain
139 duties to improve the quality, accessibility and affordability of health care in this
140 State. (NRS 439.908, 439.918) Sections 26, 34, 172 and 173 of this bill transfer the
141 Commission to the Consumer Health Division. Sections 172 and 173 also transfer
142 from the Governor to the Director of the Authority the responsibility for appointing
143 the members and Executive Director of the Commission. Sections 174 and 175 of
144 this bill require the Commission to make certain recommendations and submit certain
145 reports to the Director of the Authority.
146 Existing law authorizes the Division of Public and Behavioral Health to establish
147 a secure Internet website which makes certain information available for a website
148 client to conduct background investigations of certain persons who are required by
149 law to undergo such an investigation. (NRS 449.942) Sections 175.3 and 175.6 of
150 this bill authorize the Authority to access information on that Internet website without
151 restriction and without becoming a website client.
152 Existing law requires the Department to establish an all-payer claims database of
153 information relating to health insurance claims resulting from medical, dental or
154 pharmacy benefits provided in this State. (NRS 439B.835) Section 29 creates the
155 Office of Data Analytics within the Authority, and sections 26, 34, 202-204 and 359
156 of this bill transfer to the Office the responsibility for operating the all-payer claims
157 database.
158 Existing law: (1) requires the Division of Public and Behavioral Health to enforce
159 provisions governing sanitation and food establishments under certain
160 circumstances; and (2) requires each county where the Division provides such
161 enforcement to pay an assessment to the Division. (NRS 439.4905, chapters 444 and
162 446 of NRS) Sections 26, 34, 206-208 and 210-216 of this bill transfer to the
163 Authority the authority to enforce provisions governing sanitation and food
164 establishments, and sections 30 and 153 of this bill require counties who currently
-

– 5 –
165 pay to the Division an assessment for those functions to instead pay the assessment
166 to the Authority.
167 Existing law requires the State Board of Health to license and regulate music
168 therapists and dietitians. (Chapters 640D and 640E of NRS) Sections 26, 283-297
169 and 300-323 of this bill transfer to the Health Care Purchasing and Compliance
170 Division the responsibilities for issuing and renewing licenses to those professionals
171 and enforcing provisions of law and regulations governing those professionals and
172 leave the authority to adopt regulations governing those professions with the State
173 Board.
174 Existing law creates the Silver State Health Insurance Exchange. (NRS 695I.200)
175 Existing law requires the Exchange to: (1) create and administer a state-based health
176 insurance exchange; (2) facilitate the purchase and sale of qualified health plans; (3)
177 provide for the establishment of a program to help certain small employers in Nevada
178 in facilitating the enrollment of employees in qualified health plans; and (4) perform
179 all other duties required pursuant to the federal Patient Protection and Affordable
180 Care Act, the federal Health Care and Education Reconciliation Act of 2010 and any
181 amendments to or regulations or guidance issued pursuant to those Acts. (Pub. L. No.
182 111-148, Pub. L. No. 111-152; NRS 695I.200, 695I.210) The Exchange is governed
183 by the Board of Directors consisting of five voting members appointed by the
184 Governor, one voting member appointed by the Senate Majority Leader, one voting
185 member appointed by the Speaker of the Assembly and three ex officio, nonvoting
186 members. (NRS 695I.300) Sections 346-348 of this bill place the Exchange under
187 the authority of the Consumer Health Division. Section 348: (1) reduces the number
188 of members of the Board appointed by the Governor from five to two; (2) adds three
189 heads of agencies whose work relates to public health or health insurance as ex
190 officio, voting members of the Board; and (3) reduces the nonvoting membership of
191 the Board. Sections 349 and 350 of this bill make revisions governing the terms of
192 the members and officers of the Board. Section 352 of this bill transfers from the
193 Board to the Director of the Authority or his or her designee the responsibility for
194 appointing the Executive Director of the Exchange. Sections 351 and 352 of this bill
195 transfer certain duties relating to auditing and reports from the Board to the Executive
196 Director. Sections 353 and 354 of this bill transfer certain other duties related to the
197 Exchange to Authority and its Director.
198 Existing law requires the Director of the Department, in consultation with the
199 Commissioner of Insurance and the Executive Director of the Exchange, to design,
200 establish and operate a health benefit plan known as the Public Option. (NRS
201 695K.200) Section 355 of this bill transfers the responsibility for designing,
202 establishing and operating the Public Option to the Director of the Authority.
203 Section 27 of this bill requires the Director and the Authority to: (1) take certain
204 actions to facilitate determinations of eligibility for and the selection of plans under
205 Medicaid and certain other public health insurance programs under the jurisdiction
206 of the Authority; and (2) assess and recommend improvements to the Public
207 Employees’ Benefits Program. Sections 9-13, 38-60, 62, 77, 78, 80, 81, 83, 96-98,
208 100, 121, 123, 125, 128-139, 142, 161, 178, 179, 188, 189, 195, 196, 205, 209, 248,
209 249, 251-275, 277-280, 324, 328-336, 338-341 and 356-358 of this bill make various
210 conforming changes to reflect the authority transferred by the provisions of this bill.
211 Sections 32, 34, 38, 46, 99, 122, 127, 239, 287, 307 and 326 of this bill change the
212 name of the Division of Welfare and Supportive Services of the Department to the
213 Division of Social Services of the Department. Sections 33, 37, 82, 119, 120, 123,
214 124, 126-128 and 368 of this bill revise the terminology to refer to certain programs
215 operated by that Division from “welfare” to “public assistance.” Section 132 revises
216 the term “transitional assistance” to “child care assistance” to describe certain
217 assistance provided pursuant to federal Temporary Assistance for Needy Families
218 program. Sections 1, 16, 17, 64, 65, 85, 140, 176, 191, 192, 225, 240, 281, 298, 343
219 and 344 of this bill define certain terms, and sections 15, 67, 75, 76, 92, 177, 193,

220 201, 282, 299, 337 and 345 of this bill make conforming changes to indicate the

223 Prison Commissioners to obtain prescription drugs for the treatment of offenders
224 through collaborative purchasing conducted by the Authority for Medicaid and

226 Section 361 of this bill transfers to the Authority the duty to carry out any

229 Services to operate a program to award money to support projects to address

THE PEOPLE OF THE STATE OF NEVADA, REPRESENTED IN
SENATE AND ASSEMBLY, DO ENACT AS FOLLOWS:
1 Section 1. Chapter 223 of NRS is hereby amended by adding
2 thereto a new section to read as follows:
3 As used in NRS 223.631 to 223.639, inclusive, unless the context
4 otherwise requires, “Division” means the Consumer Health
5 Division of the Nevada Health Authority.
6 Sec. 2. NRS 223.610 is hereby amended to read as follows:
7 223.610 The Director of the Office of Science, Innovation and
8 Technology shall:
9 1. Advise the Governor and the Executive Director of the Office
10 of Economic Development on matters relating to science, innovation
11 and technology.
12 2. Work in coordination with the Office of Economic
13 Development to establish criteria and goals for economic
14 development and diversification in this State in the areas of science,
15 innovation and technology.
16 3. As directed by the Governor, identify, recommend and carry
17 out policies related to science, innovation and technology.
18 4. Report periodically to the Executive Director of the Office of
19 Economic Development concerning the administration of the policies
20 and programs of the Office of Science, Innovation and Technology.
21 5. Coordinate activities in this State relating to the planning,
22 mapping and procurement of broadband service in a competitively
23 neutral and nondiscriminatory manner, which must include, without
24 limitation:
25 (a) Development of a strategic plan to improve the delivery of
26 broadband services in this State to schools, libraries, providers of
27 health care, transportation facilities, prisons and other community
28 facilities;
-
*SB494_R1*

– 7 –
1 (b) Applying for state and federal grants on behalf of eligible
2 entities and managing state matching money that has been
3 appropriated by the Legislature;
4 (c) Coordinating and processing applications for state and federal
5 money relating to broadband services;
6 (d) Prioritizing construction projects which affect or involve the
7 expansion or deployment of broadband services in this State;
8 (e) In consultation with providers of health care from various
9 health care settings, the expansion of telehealth services to reduce
10 health care costs and increase health care quality and access in this
11 State, especially in rural, unserved and underserved areas of this
12 State;
13 (f) Expansion of the fiber optic infrastructure in this State for the
14 benefit of the public safety radio and communications systems in this
15 State;
16 (g) Collection and storage of data relating to agreements and
17 contracts entered into by the State for the provision of fiber optic
18 assets in this State;
19 (h) Administration of the trade policy for fiber optic infrastructure
20 in this State; and
21 (i) Establishing and administering a program of infrastructure
22 grants for the development or improvement of broadband services for
23 persons with low income and persons in rural areas of this State using
24 money from the Account for the Grant Program for Broadband
25 Infrastructure created by NRS 223.660. The Director may adopt
26 regulations to carry out his or duties pursuant to this paragraph.

1 Sec. 14. Chapter 232 of NRS is hereby amended by adding
2 thereto the provisions set forth as sections 15 to 31, inclusive, of this
3 act.
4 Sec. 15. As used in sections 15 to 31, inclusive, of this act,
5 unless the context otherwise requires, the words and terms defined

7 in those sections.
8 Sec. 16. “Authority” means the Nevada Health Authority.
9 Sec. 17. “Director” means the Director of the Authority.
10 Sec. 18. 1. The Nevada Health Authority is hereby created
11 as a department within the Executive Department of the State
12 Government.
13 2. The purposes of the Authority are to:
14 (a) Improve access to health care that is safe, of high quality
15 and affordable;
16 (b) Promote the development of a workforce of providers of
17 health care that is sufficient to meet the demand for health care in
18 this State;
19 (c) Ensure the availability of affordable health coverage for
20 residents of this State, including, without limitation, current and
21 retired employees of the State Government;
22 (d) Develop effective and efficient systems for delivering health
23 care and value-based strategies for procuring health insurance
24 coverage in the most sustainable and responsive manner possible;
25 and
26 (e) Ensure the long-term stability of Medicaid, the Children’s
27 Health Insurance Program, the Public Employees’ Benefits
28 Program, the Silver State Health Insurance Exchange and the
29 Public Option by minimizing the financial burden of health care on
30 persons who receive health coverage through those programs, the
31 state budget and other residents of this State through the use of
32 measures to contain costs, maximizing the impact of state and
33 federal money and the application of innovative purchasing and
34 contracting strategies.
35 3. The Authority consists of a Director and:
36 (a) The Medicaid Division;
37 (b) The Health Care Purchasing and Compliance Division; and
38 (c) The Consumer Health Division.
39 4. The Authority is the sole agency responsible for
40 administering the provisions of law relating to its respective
41 divisions.
42 Sec. 19. The Director:
43 1. Is appointed by, is responsible to, and serves at the pleasure
44 of the Governor.
45 2. Is in the unclassified service of the State.
-
*SB494_R1*

– 18 –
1 3. Except as otherwise provided in NRS 284.143, shall not
2 engage in any other gainful employment or occupation.
3 4. Must have:
4 (a) A graduate degree from an accredited college or university
5 in public health, public administration, law or a related field; and
6 (b) Broad, responsible experience in the field of administration
7 or possess broad management skills or working knowledge of the
8 field of health care or public health administration.
9 5. Must be selected with special reference to his or her
10 training, experience and aptitude for coordinating related functions
11 of public health agencies and public health insurance programs.
12 The Director’s knowledge and abilities should include the
13 following:
14 (a) A comprehensive knowledge of administrative principles,
15 and a working knowledge of principles of public finance and the
16 laws, rules and regulations pertaining to public agencies.
17 (b) Administrative ability to assess the operating efficiency of
18 component agencies and to delegate authority and duties to
19 responsible deputy directors or other personnel of the Authority.
20 (c) The ability to organize and clearly present oral and written
21 findings and recommendations to the Governor, the Legislature
22 and other officials and agencies.
23 Sec. 20. 1. The Director may employ, within the limits of

9 Sec. 24. 1. Except as otherwise provided in this section and

13 2. The Authority may, as determined by the Director, conduct
14 the process for procuring commodities and services, negotiating the
15 cost of such commodities and services and entering into contracts
16 for the provision of such commodities and services for the programs
17 under the jurisdiction of the Authority. In conducting that process,
18 the Authority may:
19 (a) Utilize a single or simultaneous competitive procurement
20 process for multiple programs to provide high value for people who
21 receive health coverage through those programs and the State
22 Government;
23 (b) Solicit and receive responses from prospective vendors by
24 posting requests for proposals, bids and documents establishing the
25 scope of work to be performed on a project and other documents on
26 an Internet website maintained by the Authority; and
27 (c) Join contracts with public or private entities in this State, the
28 District of Columbia or other states or territories of the United
29 States as appropriate to increase value for the State Government.
30 3. In consultation with the Department of Administration and
31 the Office of the Attorney General, the Authority shall adopt
32 regulations to carry out the provisions of this section. Those
33 regulations must:
34 (a) Establish processes and rules governing any committee
35 established to evaluate proposals;
36 (b) Require the provision of notice to prospective vendors who
37 submit proposals to provide commodities or services before and
38 after the Authority awards a contract;
39 (c) Provide for the confidentiality of information submitted as
40 part of a proposal and any communication between a person who
41 submits a proposal and the Authority or any members of a
42 committee described in paragraph (a);
43 (d) Prescribe the procedure for awarding a contract, which may
44 include, without limitation, procedures for:
-
*SB494_R1*

– 22 –
1 (1) An invitation to bid, a request for proposals, a request for
2 qualifications, a request for information, a request for a quote or
3 any other generally accepted procedures for awarding contracts;
4 (2) Soliciting, bidding and receiving proposals and bids
5 through an Internet website in accordance with paragraph (b) of
6 subsection 2; and
7 (3) Determining the costs of a contract for the purpose of
8 soliciting bids and responses;
9 (e) Establish preferences for bids or proposals submitted by
10 businesses based in this State, businesses owned and operated by
11 veterans with service-connected disabilities and other entities which
12 are given preferences under chapter 333 of NRS;
13 (f) Establish the duties of persons who are authorized to enter
14 into contracts on behalf of the Authority, which must be consistent
15 with the duties prescribed by NRS 333.337;
16 (g) Prescribe prohibitions consistent with NRS 333.339 against
17 entering into certain contracts;
18 (h) Prescribe procedures for determining and awarding
19 contracts to bidders who will produce results that are high in quality
20 and value;
21 (i) Procedures consistent with NRS 333.350 for:
22 (1) Awarding contracts for separate items or portions or
23 groups of items, or for separate portions of a project;
24 (2) Rejecting all bids or proposals;
25 (3) Withdrawing bids or proposals; and
26 (4) Entering records of bids and proposals;
