28 into contracts with the Authority and do not perform according to
29 the contract;
30 (k) Procedures for the submission of revised proposals;
31 (l) Procedures consistent with NRS 333.370 by which a person
32 who makes an unsuccessful bid or proposal may submit an appeal,
33 including, without limitation, requirements that such a person:
34 (1) File a notice of appeal with the Authority and the
35 Hearings Division of the Department of Administration; and
36 (2) Post a bond with good and solvent surety in a form
37 approved by the Director in an amount that is equal to or greater
38 than 25 percent of the amount of the successful bid submitted for
39 the same project;
40 (m) Procedures consistent with NRS 333.435 for purchasing
41 prescription drugs, pharmaceutical services or medical supplies and
42 related services; and
43 (n) Procedures for the awarding of contracts on a contingency
44 basis.

6 Sec. 27. 1. The Director shall:
7 (a) Enter into a contract with one or more qualified experts to

16 (1) Purchasing coverage for the programs described in this
17 subsection; and
18 (2) Strengthening networks of providers established for the
19 programs described in this section.

21 the Board of the Public Employees’ Benefits Program, solicit input
22 from the Board and make such adjustments as the Director deems
23 appropriate in response to such input.
24 (c) Within the limits of available resources, utilize the experts
25 contracted pursuant to paragraph (a) to:
26 (1) Assess and monitor the value, quality and accessibility of
27 services provided by the Public Employees’ Benefits Program to
28 participants;
29 (2) Review national best practices applicable to insurance
30 for current and retired public employees and dependents thereof;
31 (3) Make recommendations to the Board of the Public
32 Employees’ Benefits Program concerning ways to improve the
33 value, quality and accessibility of services provided to participants,
34 including, without limitation:

36 accessing and utilizing benefits;
37 (II) Measures to improve the health literacy of
38 participants, including, without limitation, participants who have
39 retired and have coverage through Medicare; and
40 (4) Provide such additional assessments and
41 recommendations as requested by the Board of the Public

-

-
*SB494_R1*

– 27 –
1 the Authority pursuant to chapters 444 and 446 of NRS and the

6 Interim Finance Committee, upon receiving the recommendation
7 from the Governor, shall consider the proposal and determine
8 whether to approve the exemption. In considering whether to
9 approve the exemption, the Interim Finance Committee shall
10 consider, among other things, the best interests of the State, the
11 effect of the exemption and the intent of the Legislature in requiring
12 the assessment to be paid by each county.

23 Sec. 31. 1. Except for gifts or grants specifically accounted
24 for in another fund, all gifts or grants of money or other property
25 which the divisions of the Authority are authorized to accept must
26 be accounted for in the Nevada Health Authority Gift Fund, which
27 is hereby created as a special revenue fund. The Fund is a
28 continuing fund without reversion. The Authority may establish
29 such accounts in the Fund as are necessary to account properly for
30 gifts received. All such money received by the divisions of the
31 Authority must be deposited in the State Treasury for credit to the
32 Fund. The money in the Fund must be paid out on claims as other
33 claims against the State are paid. Unless otherwise specifically
34 provided by statute, claims against the Fund must be approved by
35 the Director or the Director’s delegate.
36 2. Gifts of property other than money may be sold or
37 exchanged when this is deemed by the head of the agency
38 responsible for the gift to be in the best interest of the agency. The
39 sale price must not be less than 90 percent of the value determined
40 by a qualified appraiser appointed by the head of the agency. All
41 money received from the sale must be deposited in the State
42 Treasury to the credit of the appropriate gift account in the Nevada
43 Health Authority Gift Fund. The money may be spent only for the
44 purposes of the agency named in the title of the account. The
-
*SB494_R1*

1 property may not be sold or exchanged if doing so would violate the

33 Sec. 44. NRS 111.779 is hereby amended to read as follows:
34 111.779 1. Except as otherwise provided in NRS 21.090 and
35 other applicable law, a transferee of a nonprobate transfer is liable to
36 the probate estate of the decedent for allowed claims against that
37 decedent’s probate estate to the extent the estate is insufficient to
38 satisfy those claims.
39 2. The liability of a nonprobate transferee may not exceed the
40 value of nonprobate transfers received or controlled by that
41 transferee.
42 3. Nonprobate transferees are liable for the insufficiency
43 described in subsection 1 in the following order of priority:

*SB494_R1*

– 44 –

5 instrument in the decedent’s estate plan as shown by its designation
6 as devisee of the decedent’s residuary estate or by other facts or
7 circumstances, to the extent of the value of the nonprobate transfer
8 received or controlled; and
9 (c) Other nonprobate transferees, in proportion to the values
10 received.
11 4. Unless otherwise provided by the trust instrument, interests of
12 beneficiaries in all trusts incurring liabilities under this section abate
13 as necessary to satisfy the liability, as if all the trust instruments were
14 a single will and the interests were devises under it.
15 5. If a nonprobate transferee is a spouse or a minor child, the
16 nonprobate transferee may petition the court to be excluded from the
17 liability imposed by this section as if the nonprobate property
18 received by the spouse or minor child were part of the decedent’s
19 estate. Such a petition may be made pursuant to the applicable
20 provisions of chapter 146 of NRS, including, without limitation, the
21 provisions of NRS 146.010 and 146.020 and subsection 2 of
22 NRS 146.070.
23 6. A provision made in one instrument may direct the
24 apportionment of the liability among the nonprobate transferees
25 taking under that or any other governing instrument. If a provision in
26 one instrument conflicts with a provision in another, the later one
27 prevails.
28 7. Upon due notice to a nonprobate transferee, the liability
29 imposed by this section is enforceable in probate proceedings in this
30 State, whether or not the transferee is located in this State.
31 8. If a probate proceeding is pending at the time of filing and it
32 has been determined by a final order issued by the probate court that
33 there are insufficient assets to pay a valid creditor, a proceeding under
34 this section may be commenced by one of the following persons:
35 (a) The personal representative of the decedent’s estate. A
36 personal representative who declines in good faith to commence a
37 proceeding incurs no personal liability for declining.
38 (b) A creditor of the estate, if the personal representative has
39 declined or refused to commence an action within 30 days after
40 receiving a written demand by a creditor. Such demand must identify
41 the nonprobate transfers known to the creditor. If the creditor is
42 unaware of any nonprobate transfers, in the probate proceeding, the
43 creditor may, pursuant to NRS 155.170, obtain discovery, perpetuate
44 testimony or conduct examinations in any manner authorized by law
45 or by the Nevada Rules of Civil Procedure to ascertain whether any
-
*SB494_R1*

– 45 –
1 nonprobate transfers exist. If the creditor is unable to identify any
2 nonprobate transfers within a reasonable time after conducting
3 discovery, the creditor may not proceed under this section. If a
4 creditor commences an action under this section:
5 (1) The creditor must proceed at the expense of the creditor
6 and not of the estate.
7 (2) If a creditor successfully establishes an entitlement to
8 payment under this section and collects nonprobate transfers, the
9 court must order the reimbursement of the costs reasonably incurred

2 217.180 1. Except as otherwise provided in subsection 2, in

37 38 and 41 of chapter 478, Statutes of Nevada 2011 and section 2 of
38 chapter 391, Statutes of Nevada 2013 and unless otherwise declared
39 by law to be confidential, all public books and public records of a
40 governmental entity must be open at all times during office hours to
41 inspection by any person, and may be fully copied or an abstract or
42 memorandum may be prepared from those public books and public
43 records. Any such copies, abstracts or memoranda may be used to
44 supply the general public with copies, abstracts or memoranda of the
45 records or may be used in any other way to the advantage of the
-
*SB494_R1*

– 72 –
1 governmental entity or of the general public. This section does not
2 supersede or in any manner affect the federal laws governing
3 copyrights or enlarge, diminish or affect in any other manner the
4 rights of a person in any written book or record which is copyrighted
5 pursuant to federal law.
6 2. A governmental entity may not reject a book or record which
7 is copyrighted solely because it is copyrighted.
8 3. A governmental entity that has legal custody or control of a
9 public book or record shall not deny a request made pursuant to
10 subsection 1 to inspect or copy or receive a copy of a public book or
11 record on the basis that the requested public book or record contains
12 information that is confidential if the governmental entity can redact,
13 delete, conceal or separate, including, without limitation,
14 electronically, the confidential information from the information
15 included in the public book or record that is not otherwise
16 confidential.
17 4. If requested, a governmental entity shall provide a copy of a
18 public record in an electronic format by means of an electronic
19 medium. Nothing in this subsection requires a governmental entity to
20 provide a copy of a public record in an electronic format or by means
21 of an electronic medium if:
22 (a) The public record:
23 (1) Was not created or prepared in an electronic format; and
24 (2) Is not available in an electronic format; or
25 (b) Providing the public record in an electronic format or by
26 means of an electronic medium would:
27 (1) Give access to proprietary software; or
28 (2) Require the production of information that is confidential
29 and that cannot be redacted, deleted, concealed or separated from
30 information that is not otherwise confidential.
31 5. An officer, employee or agent of a governmental entity who
32 has legal custody or control of a public record:
33 (a) Shall not refuse to provide a copy of that public record in the
34 medium that is requested because the officer, employee or agent has
35 already prepared or would prefer to provide the copy in a different
36 medium.
37 (b) Except as otherwise provided in NRS 239.030, shall, upon
38 request, prepare the copy of the public record and shall not require
39 the person who has requested the copy to prepare the copy himself or
40 herself.

5 Sec. 86. 1. The Authority may delegate to another state,
6 local or tribal governmental agency the responsibility for making

9 under this chapter. If the Authority makes such a delegation, the

11 (a) Ensure compliance with the provisions of 42 C.F.R. §
12 431.10; and

14 of the Legislative Counsel Bureau for transmittal to the Legislative
15 Commission which includes:
16 (1) The state, local or tribal governmental agencies to which
17 the Authority has delegated functions;
18 (2) The functions delegated to each state, local or tribal
19 governmental agency described in subparagraph (1);
20 (3) Information concerning the performance of each state,
21 local or tribal governmental agency to which the Authority has
22 delegated a function; and
23 (4) A description of any corrective action required of a state,
24 local or tribal governmental agency to which the Authority has
25 delegated a function.
26 2. Any entity to which the Authority delegates a responsibility
27 pursuant to subsection 1 shall comply with the relevant provisions
28 of this chapter to the same extent as the Authority.
29 3. Any delegation to a local governmental agency pursuant to
30 subsection 1 must be made through an intergovernmental
31 agreement between the Authority and the local governmental
32 agency. Such an agreement must be signed by a natural person
33 acting as the agent of the local governmental agency who has the
34 legal authority to bind the local governmental agency to the
35 agreement.

37 subsection 3 delegates the responsibility for making determinations
38 concerning eligibility for Medicaid or the Children’s Health
39 Insurance Program, the agreement must include, without
40 limitation, measures to ensure compliance with applicable federal

42 eligibility.

36 Sec. 169. NRS 439.873 is hereby amended to read as follows:
37 439.873 1. A medical facility shall designate an officer or
38 employee of the facility to serve as the infection control officer of the
39 medical facility.
40 2. The person who is designated as the infection control officer
41 of a medical facility:
42 (a) Shall serve on the patient safety committee.
43 (b) Shall monitor the occurrences of infections at the medical
44 facility to determine the number and severity of infections.
-
*SB494_R1*

– 144 –
1 (c) Shall report to the patient safety committee concerning the
2 number and severity of infections at the medical facility.
3 (d) Shall take such action as he or she determines is necessary to
4 prevent and control infections alleged to have occurred at the medical
5 facility.
6 (e) Shall carry out the provisions of the infection control program
7 adopted pursuant to NRS 439.865 and ensure compliance with the
8 program.
9 3. If a medical facility has 175 or more beds, the person who is
10 designated as the infection control officer of the medical facility must
11 be certified as an infection preventionist by the Certification Board of
12 Infection Control and Epidemiology, Inc., or a successor
13 organization. A person may serve as the certified infection
14 preventionist for more than one medical facility if the facilities have
15 common ownership.
16 4. A medical facility that designates an infection control officer
17 who is not a certified infection preventionist must ensure that the
18 person has successfully completed a nationally recognized basic
19 training program in infection control, which may include, without
20 limitation, the program offered by the Association for Professionals
21 in Infection Control and Epidemiology, Inc., or a successor
22 organization. A medical facility shall ensure that an infection control
23 officer completes at least 4 hours of continuing education each year
24 on topics relating to current practices in infection control and
25 prevention.
26 5. A medical facility shall ensure that it maintains a ratio of at
27 least one employee who has the training described in subsection 4 for
28 every 100 occupied beds. The number of beds must be determined
29 based upon the most recent annual calendar-year average reported by
30 the medical facility to the Director of the Authority pursuant to NRS
31 449.490 and the regulations adopted pursuant thereto.
32 6. A medical facility shall maintain records concerning the
33 certification and training required by this section.

19 NRS 439.942, the Division shall determine the information necessary
20 for the website client to conduct an investigation into the background
21 and personal history of a person and limit access to the website client
22 to only the information necessary for that website client.
23 2. Information regarding a person whose background and
24 personal history is investigated must not be shared with any other
25 website client.
26 3. A person who is authorized to use the Internet website by the
27 website client administrator pursuant to NRS 439.942 may be given
28 permission to access any information deemed necessary pursuant to
29 subsection 1.
30 4. The Authority or any division thereof may access
31 information on the Internet website established pursuant to NRS

44 3. In reviewing an application for approval, the Director shall:
-
*SB494_R1*

– 155 –
1 (a) Comparatively assess applications for similar projects
2 affecting the same geographic area; and
3 (b) Base his or her decision on criteria established by the Director
4 by regulation. The criteria must include:
5 (1) The need for and the appropriateness of the project in the
6 area to be served;
7 (2) The financial feasibility of the project;
8 (3) The effect of the project on the cost of health care; and
9 (4) The extent to which the project is consistent with the
10 purposes set forth in NRS 439A.020 and the priorities set forth in
11 NRS 439A.081, including, without limitation:
12 (I) The impact of the project on other health care facilities;
13 (II) The need for any equipment that the project proposes
14 to add, the manner in which such equipment will improve the quality
15 of health care and any protocols provided in the project for avoiding
16 repetitive testing;
17 (III) The impact of the project on disparate health
18 outcomes for different populations in the area that will be served by
19 the project;
20 (IV) The manner in which the project will expand, promote
21 or enhance the capacity to provide primary health care in the area that
22 will be served by the project;
23 (V) Any plan by the applicant to collect and analyze data
24 concerning the effect of the project on health care quality and patient
25 outcomes in the area served by the project;
26 (VI) Any plan by the applicant for controlling the spread
27 of infectious diseases; and
28 (VII) The manner in which the applicant will coordinate
29 with and support existing health facilities and practitioners, including,
30 without limitation, mental health facilities, programs for the treatment
31 and prevention of substance use disorders and providers of nursing
32 services.
33 4. The Department may by regulation require additional
34 approval for a proposed change to a project which has previously
35 been approved if the proposal would result in a change in the location
36 of the project or a substantial increase in the cost of the project.
37 5. The decision of the Director is a final decision for the
38 purposes of judicial review.
39 6. As used in this section, “hospital” has the meaning ascribed
40 to it in NRS 449.012.

37 physician working in the hospital is entitled to recover from that
38 hospital an amount equal to three times the charges for the treatment
39 provided that was billed by the physician, hospital or other health
40 facility which provided the treatment, plus reasonable attorney’s fees
41 and costs.
42 4. This section does not prohibit the transfer of a patient from
43 one hospital to another:
-
*SB494_R1*

– 166 –
1 (a) When the patient is covered by an insurance policy or other
2 contractual arrangement which provides for payment at the receiving
3 hospital;
4 (b) After the county responsible for payment for the care of an
5 indigent patient has exhausted the money which may be appropriated
6 for that purpose pursuant to NRS 428.050, 428.285 and 450.425; or
7 (c) When the hospital cannot provide the services needed by the
8 patient.
9  No transfer may be made pursuant to this subsection until the
10 patient’s condition has been stabilized to a degree that allows the
11 transfer without an additional risk to the patient.
12 5. As used in this section:
13 (a) “Emergency services and care” means medical screening,
14 examination and evaluation by a physician or, to the extent permitted
15 by a specific statute, by a person under the supervision of a physician,
16 to determine if an emergency medical condition or active labor exists
17 and, if it does, the care, treatment and surgery by a physician
18 necessary to relieve or eliminate the emergency medical condition or
19 active labor, within the capability of the hospital. As used in this
20 paragraph:
21 (1) “Active labor” means, in relation to childbirth, labor that
22 occurs when:
23 (I) There is inadequate time before delivery to transfer the
24 patient safely to another hospital; or
25 (II) A transfer may pose a threat to the health and safety of
26 the patient or the unborn child.
27 (2) “Emergency medical condition” means the presence of
28 acute symptoms of sufficient severity, including severe pain, such
29 that the absence of immediate medical attention could reasonably be
30 expected to result in:
31 (I) Placing the health of the patient in serious jeopardy;
32 (II) Serious impairment of bodily functions; or
33 (III) Serious dysfunction of any bodily organ or part.
34 (b) “Medically fit” means that the condition of the patient has
35 been sufficiently stabilized so that the patient may be safely
36 transported to another hospital, or is such that, in the determination
37 of the attending physician, the transfer of the patient constitutes an
38 acceptable risk. Such a determination must be based upon the
39 condition of the patient, the expected benefits, if any, to the patient
40 resulting from the transfer and whether the risks to the patient’s health
41 are outweighed by the expected benefits, and must be documented in
42 the patient’s records before the transfer.
43 6. If an allegation of a violation of the provisions of subsection
44 2 is made against a hospital licensed pursuant to the provisions of
45 chapter 449 of NRS, the Health Care Purchasing and Compliance
-
*SB494_R1*

– 167 –
1 Division of [Public and Behavioral Health of the Department] the
2 Authority shall conduct an investigation of the alleged violation.
3 Such a violation, in addition to any criminal penalties that may be
4 imposed, constitutes grounds for the denial, suspension or revocation
5 of such a license, or for the imposition of any sanction prescribed by
6 NRS 449.163.
7 7. If an allegation of a violation of the provisions of subsection
8 2 is made against:
9 (a) A physician licensed to practice medicine pursuant to the
10 provisions of chapter 630 of NRS, the Board of Medical Examiners
11 shall conduct an investigation of the alleged violation. Such a
12 violation, in addition to any criminal penalties that may be imposed,
13 constitutes grounds for initiating disciplinary action or denying
14 licensure pursuant to the provisions of subsection 3 of
15 NRS 630.3065.
16 (b) An osteopathic physician licensed to practice osteopathic
17 medicine pursuant to the provisions of chapter 633 of NRS, the State
18 Board of Osteopathic Medicine shall conduct an investigation of the
19 alleged violation. Such a violation, in addition to any criminal
20 penalties that may be imposed, constitutes grounds for initiating
21 disciplinary action pursuant to the provisions of subsection 1 of NRS
22 633.131.

38 anesthesiologist assistant, within 30 days after the change in
39 privileges is made or disciplinary action is taken.
40 4. A hospital, clinic or other medical facility licensed in this
41 State, or medical society, shall report to the Board within 5 days after
42 a change in the privileges of an osteopathic physician, physician
43 assistant or anesthesiologist assistant that is based on:
-
*SB494_R1*

– 215 –
1 (a) An investigation of the mental, medical or psychological
2 competency of the osteopathic physician, physician assistant or
3 anesthesiologist assistant; or
4 (b) A suspected or alleged substance use disorder in any form by
5 the osteopathic physician, physician assistant or anesthesiologist
6 assistant.
7 5. The Board shall report any failure to comply with subsection
8 3 or 4 by a hospital, clinic or other medical facility licensed in this
9 State to the Health Care Purchasing and Compliance Division of
10 [Public and Behavioral Health of the Department of Health and
11 Human Services.] the Nevada Health Authority. If, after a hearing,
12 the Division determines that any such facility or society failed to
13 comply with the requirements of subsection 3 or 4, the Division may
14 impose an administrative fine of not more than $10,000 against the
15 facility or society for each such failure to report. If the administrative
16 fine is not paid when due, the fine must be recovered in a civil action
17 brought by the Attorney General on behalf of the Division.
18 6. The clerk of every court shall report to the Board any finding,
19 judgment or other determination of the court that an osteopathic
20 physician, physician assistant or anesthesiologist assistant:
21 (a) Is mentally ill;
22 (b) Is mentally incompetent;
23 (c) Has been convicted of a felony or any law governing
24 controlled substances or dangerous drugs;
25 (d) Is guilty of abuse or fraud under any state or federal program
26 providing medical assistance; or
27 (e) Is liable for damages for malpractice or negligence,
28  within 45 days after the finding, judgment or determination.

21 facility. The sealed container must be stored at all times in a locked
22 compartment on the premises of the facility.
23 3. All drugs delivered to a facility must be signed for by the
24 nurse or other person in charge. An inventory of the stock of drugs
25 must be appended to the sealed container. Immediately after the drugs
26 are needed, the physician or registered nurse who breaks the seal shall
27 enter on the inventory sheet the following information:
28 (a) The date and time the sealed container is opened;
29 (b) The name of the patient for whom the drugs are to be used;
30 (c) The name of the patient’s physician or the physician who
31 directs the administration of the drugs, if different;
32 (d) An itemization of the drugs removed; and
33 (e) The signature of the person who opened the sealed container.
34 4. When the drugs have been removed and the information
35 required by subsection 3 has been entered on the inventory, the
36 physician or registered nurse shall immediately replace the container
37 in a locked compartment and shall notify the pharmaceutical
38 consultant, as soon as it is practical to do so, that the container has
39 been opened.
40 5. The sealed container and its contents at all times remain the
41 responsibility of the pharmaceutical consultant. Upon being notified
42 that the sealed container has been opened, or on the next business day
43 if notification is not received during business hours, but in no event
44 more than 48 hours following receipt of the notification, the
45 pharmaceutical consultant shall:
-
*SB494_R1*

– 219 –
1 (a) Examine the inventory sheet;
2 (b) Replace the drugs removed;
3 (c) Secure a written prescription for the drugs replaced, if one is
4 required by law;
5 (d) Enter the name and quantity of the drugs so replaced on the
6 inventory sheet, together with the date and time of replacement;
7 (e) Reseal the container; and
8 (f) Sign the inventory sheet.
9 6. No person other than a licensed physician or registered nurse
